text: Donald John Trump was born on June 14, 1946, at Jamaica Hospital in the New York City borough of Queens, the fourth child of Fred Trump and Mary Anne MacLeod Trump.

Albert Einstein (born March 14, 1879, died April 18, 1955) was a German-born physicist who revolutionized our understanding of the universe with his theories of relativity. He also won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect.

Edgar Allan Poe was an American author known for his contributions to horror, detective fiction, and science fiction genres. He was a short-story writer, poet, critic, and editor, famous for his exploration of mystery and the macabre. He is credited with creating the detective fiction genre with stories like "The Murders in the Rue Morgue," which introduces the character of C. Auguste Dupin.
